channel.title: Comments on: TypeScript Compiling into Single JavaScript File
channel.description: Manage Your Code Snippets with codeBelt | Code Examples / Tutorials / Articles

item.title: By: David
item.dc:creator: David
item.description:
Regarding compiling to single file, the default with the Visual Studio plugin is to compile each file into a separate .js file, which it does by specifying all the files in the -out parameter. I think it assumes that you're typically using it in a ASP.NET project which if you're using the MVC4 bundler, it will use the unminified files when you're in debug mode, and use the a combined minified file when you're in release mode.
If you're not using it in an ASP.NET MVC4 app, then the single file compile is probably more convenient.
item.content:encoded:
Regarding compiling to single file, the default with the Visual Studio plugin is to compile each file into a separate .js file, which it does by specifying all the files in the -out parameter. I think it assumes that you’re typically using it in a ASP.NET project which if you’re using the MVC4 bundler, it will use the unminified files when you’re in debug mode, and use the a combined minified file when you’re in release mode.

If you’re not using it in an ASP.NET MVC4 app, then the single file compile is probably more convenient.
